answers.answer: From  what you say it appears to me the subject needs to be on an anticoagulant (coumadin/warfarin), hope he is.In general any mental activity that requires thinking/analysis/recalling should help memory.  I don't have any specific exercises focused on numbers, but repetition should help remember specific numbers: e.g., wife's telephone.  Give him a tablet and pencil and ask him to write the phone number at least 5 times, each time covering the past records before writing again each morning after breakfast, say.

question: What is the percentage of Americans who are born with a hole in the lower part of the heart?  Is this something that an adult should worry about beyond the recent diagnosis for type II diabetes, high blood pressure, blood clots in the back of the head, and two recent strokes.  The adult is male and in his 70's.  He has been going through daily Occupational Therapy and has gained strength back on the left side of his body.  He is able to get himself into the wheelchair and at the end of the day he can get out of the wheelchair to get back on his bed.  His therapy consists of hand therapy and walking to get stronger.  Any further recommendations?  Today this adult is losing his memory for phone numbers.  Example his wife's phone number is hard for him to remember.  If you have suggested memory exercises that will be much appreciated.
title: Hole in the heart
